It seems that the key could be the same, for different boards. 
For example :
If there only one piece in both hands. It'd be the same if the piece is in player0's hand or player1's hand.

You could add a background color (red/blue) to the avatar frame (or color the name like in some multis). 
It would be easier to see which player is 1 or 2 (especially when the avatars are the same : wala vs wala...)

Hi Jacek,
It would be nice if the random moves could use the seed.
So the random bots would be deterministic..
It can be done with :
Collections.shuffle(availableMoves, gameManager.getRandom());

Threefold repetition and perpetual check

* Please change "doesn't need to" to "need not" (or at least change "doesn't" to "don't").

* Is it always Player 0 who loses? Can it be Player 1? Should the explanation be rewritten as follows?

If on a player's turn the same position (etc.), the game ends and the player loses.

Victory / Loss Conditions

* Repeat(s) position for 3rd time while giving check. <- Isn't threefold repetition itself (without check) sufficient to be a loss condition?

Thanks.

In the statement, the dark text is difficult to read. White text over yellow is also difficult to read. On the timeline, dark milestones are difficult to see.
Except for the color choices, the contribution looks good to me. The same comments apply to the twin contribution.
Changed to threefold repetition. As far as bot games concern, even twofold repetition would suffice, but let's make it still entertaining for humans,
For discussion: what to do with fourfold repetition. There is no consensus it seems.

The official rule is four times.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sennichite
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minishogi

It is not a big deal, but I prefer four times a little. Otherwise I will have to add a special flag to my program to handle this unusual codingame rule.
Oh, it also depends what color mode you're using :thinking:. I'll find some suitable colors.
It is lose for Player 0/first/black always. Unless the repeated position is giving check to a king, then the checking side loses, it is sufficient to avoid perpetual check.

I believe color names will be better.
https://imgur.com/a/viI8u2O
Oops that was a typo. Fixed.
Now fixed. I was thinking about using separate randoms for players, so that one player wouldn't consume the same random instance, but meh. It's quite minor thing.

Thank you for making the change, but "need not to be" should be changed to "need not be".

What a strange rule that it must be Player 0 which loses, but I just don't know the game to make an informed comment.

Based on the current description, Player 0 can lose under threefold repetition even when a King is not in check. This condition is not shown in the Loss Conditions section and should be added, right?

Thanks again.

The reason it is only losing for player 0 is that player 0 has the first move advantage. It forces the player to progress the board, as opposed to staying in a sort of strategic zugzwang with no captures.

I guess it would also work if it was losing for either player.  The perpetual check part *is*  losing for either player though. At least those are the official tournament rules.
On a light background, things are reversed but no better
Changed so it is more like other games on CG. Though I wonder if it's confusing that red is black :thinking_face:
Yep, much better
